memberdef.definition: limbo::model::GP< Params, KernelFunction, MeanFunction, HyperParamsOptimizer >::GP
memberdef.name: GP

briefdescription.para: useful because the model might be created before knowing anything about the process

memberdef.definition: limbo::model::GP< Params, KernelFunction, MeanFunction, HyperParamsOptimizer >::GP
memberdef.name: GP

briefdescription.para: useful because the model might be created before having samples

memberdef.definition: void limbo::model::GP< Params, KernelFunction, MeanFunction, HyperParamsOptimizer >::compute
memberdef.argsstring: (const std::vector< Eigen::VectorXd > &samples, const std::vector< Eigen::VectorXd > &observations, const Eigen::VectorXd &noises, const std::vector< Eigen::VectorXd > &bl_samples=std::vector< Eigen::VectorXd >(), const Eigen::VectorXd &noises_bl=Eigen::VectorXd())
memberdef.name: compute

briefdescription.para: Compute the GP from samples, observation, noise. [optional: blacklisted samples]. This call needs to be explicit!

memberdef.definition: void limbo::model::GP< Params, KernelFunction, MeanFunction, HyperParamsOptimizer >::optimize_hyperparams
memberdef.name: optimize_hyperparams

briefdescription.para: Do not forget to call this if you use hyper-prameters optimization!!

memberdef.definition: void limbo::model::GP< Params, KernelFunction, MeanFunction, HyperParamsOptimizer >::add_sample
memberdef.name: add_sample

detaileddescription.para: add sample and update the GP. This code uses an incremental implementation of the Cholesky decomposition. It is therefore much faster than a call to compute()

memberdef.definition: void limbo::model::GP< Params, KernelFunction, MeanFunction, HyperParamsOptimizer >::add_bl_sample
memberdef.name: add_bl_sample

briefdescription.para: add blacklisted sample and update the GP

memberdef.definition: std::tuple<Eigen::VectorXd, double> limbo::model::GP< Params, KernelFunction, MeanFunction, HyperParamsOptimizer >::query
memberdef.name: query

detaileddescription.para: \rst return :math:\mu, :math:\sigma^2 (unormalized). If there is no sample, return the value according to the mean function. Using this method instead of separate calls to mu() and sigma() is more efficient because some computations are shared between mu() and sigma(). \endrst

memberdef.definition: Eigen::VectorXd limbo::model::GP< Params, KernelFunction, MeanFunction, HyperParamsOptimizer >::mu
memberdef.name: mu

detaileddescription.para: \rst return :math:\mu (unormalized). If there is no sample, return the value according to the mean function. \endrst

memberdef.definition: double limbo::model::GP< Params, KernelFunction, MeanFunction, HyperParamsOptimizer >::sigma
memberdef.name: sigma

detaileddescription.para: \rst return :math:\sigma^2 (unormalized). If there is no sample, return the max :math:\sigma^2. \endrst

detaileddescription.para:
A classic Gaussian process. It is parametrized by:
a mean function
[optionnal] an optimizer for the hyper-parameters
